B) The body rejects foreign tissues only
C) The body stops producing white blood cells

D) Red blood cells and platelets

D) The removal of antigens from the body

options: A) By increasing blood flow to infected areas
B) By marking pathogens for destruction by other immune cells

options: A) It remains attached to the vessel wall
B) It travels through the bloodstream to other locations
D) It is formed outside the vascular system

UnitD.question: What differentiates the innate and adaptive immune responses?

B) Adaptive responses are general and non-specific
C) Innate responses are immediate and non-specific
D) Adaptive responses do not remember pathogens

UnitD.question: Which mechanism describes how vaccines work at the cellular level?

B) They stimulate the production of T-cells that remain inactive
C) They encourage the immune system to remember pathogens
D) They suppress the immune system to prevent overreaction

UnitD.question: What is the role of suppressor T-cells in the immune system?
options: A) They enhance the immune response
B) They regulate or suppress other cells in the immune system

UnitD.question: What is the primary action of histamine in allergic reactions?
options: C) It causes inflammation and bronchoconstriction
D) It heals the affected tissues

B) The immune system attacks healthy body tissue
C) The immune system produces excess antibodies
D) The immune system stops producing white blood cells

UnitD.question: What differentiates an antibiotic from a vaccine?
options: A) Antibiotics stimulate the immune system; vaccines do not
B) Antibiotics kill bacteria; vaccines prevent viral infections
C) Antibiotics are used to treat infections; vaccines are used to prevent them
D) Antibiotics are natural; vaccines are synthetic

UnitD.question: How does antibiotic resistance occur?
options: A) Through genetic mutations in viruses
B) When bacteria mutate and are no longer affected by antibiotics
C) When the body becomes immune to antibiotics
D) When antibiotics are taken with vaccines

UnitD.question: Which is a primary function of memory T-cells in the adaptive immune response?
options: A) To initiate immediate response to pathogens
B) To produce antibodies during initial exposure
C) To remember pathogens and respond faster upon re-exposure
D) To regulate blood clotting during infection

UnitD.question: What is the primary function of nasal hairs?
options: B) To filter dust and other particles

options: A) It helps in tasting the air

D) It cools the body down

D) The total volume of the lungs

options: D) Encapsulated in red blood cells

D) The minimum inhale after a maximum exhale

D) It warms the air entering the lungs

D) The air remaining after a forceful exhale

D) Hydrogen levels in the blood

UnitD.question: What happens when carbon dioxide levels in the blood rise?

D) It has no effect on gas exchange
